title: What is the best big block Chevy engine? - Quora

response.answer_text: I happen to be very fond of the the L-88 427 engines. This fondness is directly related to personal experience as I had the chance to drive a 1968 L-88 Corvette back in 1973. It was by far the fastest car I’ve ever driven and I remember it fondly to this day. And I could have purchased that car for around $2,800.00 back then. But I could not have afforded the insurance. Today a nice example will sell for over a million dollars. I still have nightmares about that!!! Not only would I like to be a millionaire but I’d just love to drive that damned thing again… 🤣🤣🤣. Even though I’m almost 66 years old. But I digress… The L-88 was a race engine that you could order as an option in the 1967 through 1969 Corvettes; if you and your dealership could navigate the Central Office Production Order process. Along with a sturdy lower end, it had a radical solid lifter camshaft, 12.5 to 1 compression ratio, aluminum cylinder heads, aluminum high rise intake and 850 cfm Holley carburetor. You could drive it on the street but it wasn’t pleasant. Rated at a conservative 430hp it produced a realistic 550hp. Just a little over 200 Corvettes were built with the L-88 option during the production run. However…. The L-88 Corvettes would be trumped by the ZL-1 1969 Camaros. The ZL-1 was essentially a L-88 engine with an aluminum block. It was only available in the 1969 Camaro through, again, a Central Office Production Order (COPO). I think only 50 or so of these vehicles were built and are extremely valuable today. I love Chevy big blocks. I’ve owned both a 396 and 454 Chevelle. And my boat has a 454 engine. But to illustrate the strides we have made in engine efficiency and performance, a well tuned and driven L-88 or ZL-1 would be around a 12 second car in the quarter mile. My son-in-law has a late model Mustang. 5.0 liter engine. Whipple supercharger. Bigger injectors. Performance tune. And a few other odds and ends. You can drive it anywhere in comfort and get 20 mpg. And it’s a 10.5 second car. Scares the heck out of me!!! ZL-1 Engine  ZL-1 Camaro… Doesn’t look like much, does it?  Pictures courtesy of Google.

thats an easy one for me. the best big block chevy engine is the 454. the 454 could be had from mild to wild . powered station wagons , pick up trucks , boats and were a favourite for tractor pulls . reliable big torque engine for trailer towing the 454 was a very good robust engine that could tackle any big job. i remember i was in GEORGIA IN 1974 and the state trooper came in the gas station we were at and he was driving a 1974 chev with 454 on the fender. even the cops liked them. i remember when i was in trade school and we had a donated 1973 caprice fully loaded with a 454 . it was on a car carrier that fipped so the trade school got it and repaired it. so we put it on the dyno and it pulled 255 horses at the rear wheels which i thought was pretty damn impressive for a smog engine.
